author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: In Berlin, Opera Scales Up to Fill an Airport Hangar
description: With its home theater under renovation, the Komische Oper branches out, beginning with Henze’s “The Raft of the Medusa” at Tempelhof Airport.
content: The 1816 wreck of the French frigate Medusa, from which just a handful of passengers survived after nearly two weeks on a makeshift raft, was still very recent history when Théodore Géricault painted the scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Kellen Browning
title: Instacart Prices I.P.O. at $30 a Share, Raising $660 Million
description: The grocery delivery company priced its offering at the high end of expectations, in a potentially upbeat sign for tech public offerings.
content: Instacart on Monday priced its shares at $30 each for its initial public offering, at the top of its expected range, in a sign of renewed demand for tech stocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: If You Live Near the U.N., It’s a Good Week to Get Out of Town
description: It will be a “high-level week” when the General Assembly kicks off, which means extra gridlock for residents of United Nations Plaza.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll meet people who say the United Nations General Assembly’s “high-level week” is a high-level ordeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Unions Keep Up Their Hardball Tactics
description: In contract disputes from Detroit to Hollywood, organized labor leaders are holding firm in their efforts to gain more pay and job security for members.
content: The U.A.W.’s strike against the big three Detroit carmakers appears unlikely to end soon, with the two sides giving little sign that either will bend significantly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: The Amber Gleam of Yakgwa, South Korea’s ‘It’ Cookie
description: These glossy cookies come from ancient Korea, but their ginger-honey flavors are timeless.
content: Once, when the chef Junghyun Park was young, his cousin brought a piece of fresh honeycomb over to his house in Seoul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Acquitted by the Texas Senate, Ken Paxton Still Faces Legal Problems
description: The State Senate acquitted the attorney general on charges of corruption and abuse of office, but he still faces trial on securities fraud charges and a federal corruption investigation.
content: Ken Paxton, the embattled attorney general of Texas, survived an impeachment vote in the State Senate over the weekend, but the case is far from behind him: The U.S. Justice Department still has an open investigation over many of the same allegations of corruption and abuse of office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Haley Willis, Malachy Browne, Christoph Koettl and Alexander Cardia
title: Evidence Suggests Ukrainian Missile Caused Market Tragedy
description: Witness accounts and an analysis of video and weapon fragments suggest a Ukrainian missile failed to hit its intended target and landed in a bustling street, with devastating consequences.
content: The Sept. 6 missile strike on Kostiantynivka in eastern Ukraine was one of the deadliest in the country in months, killing at least 15 civilians and injuring more than 30 others. The weapon’s payload of metal fragments struck a market, piercing windows and walls and wounding some victims beyond recognition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Johnny Diaz
title: Former N.F.L. Player Sergio Brown Missing After His Mother Is Found Dead
description: The police in Maywood, a Chicago suburb, have been looking for Mr. Brown, 35, since Saturday.
content: The police in Illinois were searching for the former N.F.L. player Sergio Brown after his mother was found dead from multiple injuries related to an assault near a creek behind her home on Saturday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root
title: Scandal-Plagued Migrant Services Firm Could Limit New York’s Options
description: The New York City comptroller is auditing a no-bid $432 million migrant-services contract, and could scrap Mayor Eric Adams’s authority to make such deals unilaterally.
content: As the migrant situation worsens in New York City, Mayor Eric Adams is in danger of forfeiting his ability to quickly spend hundreds of millions of dollars on the crisis using his emergency powers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Empty Offices, Empty Storefronts
description: What should be done with the empty space? Also: Aid to Ukraine; a climate emergency; what home organizers see.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: The Senate Dress Code Gets a Casual Overhaul
description: Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, will no longer enforce the informal dress code for the chamber, which for decades has dictated that members wear business attire.
content: In the tradition-bound halls of the Senate, customs die hard and rules can be next to impossible to change. But on Monday, with a potential government shutdown days away, a newly begun impeachment inquiry and lawmakers preparing for a visit this week from the president of Ukraine, a major change had the Capitol abuzz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Releases 5 Americans as U.S. Unfreezes Billions in Oil Revenue for Tehran
description: The terms of the deal have generated intense criticism from Republicans, even as the White House insists Iran will be prevented from spending the money on anything except humanitarian goods.
content: Five Americans who had been imprisoned in Iran were allowed to leave the country on Monday, President Biden said, after two years of high-stakes negotiations in which the United States agreed to unfreeze $6 billion in Iranian oil revenue and dismiss federal charges against five Iranians accused of violating U.S. sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: McCarthy’s Plan to Avoid a Shutdown Hits Stiff G.O.P. Opposition
description: Republican leaders were hoping to pass the combination of spending cuts and border controls to show they were working to forestall a shutdown and pressure the Senate, but the bill’s prospects looked grim.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s bid to gain the upper hand in a battle over federal spending hit stiff opposition from within his own ranks on Monday, leaving him with dwindling options and little time to find his way out of a funding impasse that could lead to a government shutdown in less than two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: A $4 Thrift Store Find That Could Sell for $250,000
description: A woman found a rare N.C. Wyeth illustration while rummaging though frames at a Savers in New Hampshire. Now the piece is expected to draw a significant sum at auction.
content: You can walk out of the Savers in Manchester, N.H., with a shirt for as little as $4.99. There are $2 rings for those interested in costume jewelry. Framed artworks too big for shelves lean invitingly against one of the walls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Bill Maher Reverses Decision to Restart Show
description: Mr. Maher said he changed his mind about resuming his weekly HBO show because negotiations in the screenwriters’ strike were set to continue this week.
content: Bill Maher said on Monday that he would delay the return of his show, just days after he had said it would resume despite the ongoing screenwriters’ strike against Hollywood studios.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: The espionage shadow war by China and the U.S.
content: China and the U.S. are taking bold steps in their espionage shadow war to try to collect intelligence on leadership thinking and military capabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: When Fiji Beats Australia, and It Almost Isn’t an Upset
description: The Pacific Island nations, hardly sports powers, can hold their own and then some in rugby.
content: Fiji, population 900,000, defeated Australia, population 25 million, at the Rugby World Cup in St. Etienne, France, on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Szalay
title: ‘The Box’ Is a Modernist Puzzle in the Vein of Kafka and Joyce
description: Mandy-Suzanne Wong’s new novel follows a white paper box on a disorienting journey through many hands — none of which can open it.
content: Some novels start with the promise, What I’m about to tell you actually happened; others propose, Let’s play a game. “The Box” is among the latter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim, Vivian Nereim and Hwaida Saad
title: From Flood-Ravaged Ruins, Libyans Demand Accountability
description: The cries of protesters were part of a rising chorus of calls for answers from leaders across a divided Libya, specifically for an international investigation.
content: Hundreds of Libyans protested on Monday from the devastated eastern city of Derna, demanding the removal of those responsible a week after torrential rains burst two dams and unleashed a catastrophe that killed thousands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: The Queen of West African Recipes Has Entered the Chat
description: Thieboudienne, the national dish of Senegal, shows how sophisticated and delicious a one-pot rice dish can be.
content: Thieboudienne holds a special place among the cuisines of West Africa. This one-pot rice masterpiece is often referred to as the national dish of Senegal, yet its presence and popularity extend beyond any national borders. Its influence is powerful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Rosenfeld and Daniel Schlozman
title: The Republican Party Has Devolved Into a Racket
description: The G.O.P. has lost a commitment to solving the nation’s problems and become purposeless.
content: This is the Republican Party today. In the House, Speaker Kevin McCarthy, trying to corral a fractious majority, has ordered an impeachment inquiry into President Biden over his son’s financial entanglements, even as elements in his caucus push to shut down the government unless there are drastic cuts in spending. In the Senate, Mitt Romney announced his plan to retire, having declared to his biographer that “a very large portion of my party really doesn’t believe in the Constitution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Has Money Affected Your Relationships? Tell Us Your Stories.
description: Send us your true stories about how money has complicated or transformed your relationships, for possible inclusion in a Modern Love project.
content: In relationships, money may be the most taboo of subjects. Yet it can evoke a world of complicated emotions: shame, envy, anxiety, pride, panic, trust, possibility. And it can create a host of tricky situations: the partner who earns more versus the partner who has to do more domestically (or the partner who does both); a welcomed feeling of financial independence after divorce; family members at odds over an inheritance; friendships or romantic relationships that feel out of balance because of a difference in class status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Ukraine says it is bringing a complaint to the W.T.O. about grain bans by Poland, Slovakia and Hungary.
description: The countries said the bans were necessary to protect their own farmers, who were concerned that cheap grain from Ukraine had pushed down prices.
content: Ukraine said on Monday it was filing a complaint with the World Trade Organization against Poland, Slovakia and Hungary after the three countries broke with the rest of the European Union to ban imports of Ukrainian grain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Donor Who Backed DeSantis Re-election Is ‘Still on the Sidelines’ in 2024
description: The hedge fund billionaire Kenneth Griffin supported Gov. Ron DeSantis’s campaign in Florida last year, but has not backed a Republican for president.
content: Kenneth Griffin, a billionaire hedge-fund executive and major Republican donor who has made it clear that he wants the party to move on from former President Donald J. Trump, still has yet to settle on an alternative in the primary — even as time dwindles for Mr. Trump’s opponents to cut into his enormous lead before voting begins in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams and José F. Costa
title: In This Vacation Home, the Art Is the View
description: A house in Portugal’s Alentejo region lets the landscape dominate.
content: The experience of entering Eddie Roschi’s country home in the Alentejo region of southern Portugal is purposefully disorienting. The first thing you see, from the end of a long dirt drive, is a monumental boomerang-shaped concrete facade, 150 feet long and 11 feet high. “When imagining a house on this beautiful land,” says Roschi, the co-founder of the fragrance company Le Labo, “my first idea was to create a space where you’d immediately be confronted with an obstruction.” A narrow opening at the center of the building reveals a small courtyard anchored by an oak tree, and two doors, each a featureless plank made from eco-friendly Kebony wood (a sustainably harvested pine modified for hardiness) that wraps around the single-story house. Both doors open onto long, dark hallways; one runs through the east wing, the other through the west wing. Take a few steps down either hallway, turn south and you’re suddenly standing in a cavernous 1,800-square-foot space: part living room, part dining room and kitchen, all sheathed in Kebony. In place of a back wall, there are 115 feet of sliding glass doors, angled to appear like a massive bay window. On a sunny day, it can take a few seconds for your eyes to adjust to both the light and the expansive view of wildflower fields, grasses, holm oak trees and olive groves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Learn to Make Homemade Bagels for the Yom Kippur Break Fast
description: Cook from the World Central Kitchen cookbook, try a new Hawaiian sauces and more food news.
content: After the fast ends at sundown on Yom Kippur in many households, the meal of choice comes from the appetizing counter, with smoked fish, cream cheese and bagels. This year those bagels might be homemade if you participate in a class given by the bagel experts Reva Castellenti and Sam Silverman on Saturday at 4 or 6:30 p.m., at Bagel Market in Midtown. Or perhaps you’d just want to learn how to make bagels without any observance. Either way, the two-hour hands-on session involves rolling, boiling, seeding and baking the bagels, and taking a dozen of them home. Bagels to eat with spreads, plus beer and wine, will be served and bagel history will be revealed. There will also be a three-hour class to break the fast on Monday, Sept. 25, at 6 p.m., with more food to eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Wasserman Merges Sports and Entertainment by Buying Brillstein
description: Casey Wasserman had long pledged to stay away from the traditional entertainment business, but he said a new media landscape changed his thinking.
content: For decades, Casey Wasserman has insisted that he would never enter the traditional entertainment business. Film and TV felt too incestuous — his grandfather Lew Wasserman reigned as Hollywood’s power broker from the 1960s to the 1990s — and too financially challenged, he would say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: armature
description: This word has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word armature has appeared in 20 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 24 in “What’s Inside a Butter Cow? It’s Not Just Butter” by Amanda Holpuch:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: I.R.S. Changes Audit Practice That Discriminated Against Black Taxpayers
description: The agency will overhaul how it scrutinizes returns that claim the earned-income tax credit, which is aimed at alleviating poverty.
content: The Internal Revenue Service is overhauling how it scrutinizes the tax returns of lower-income Americans as part of an effort to reduce enforcement disparities that have made Black taxpayers far more likely than anyone else to be audited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien and Chris Buckley
title: China Sends Record Number of Military Planes Near Taiwan
description: Taiwan’s defense ministry criticized the uptick in Chinese military activity, saying Beijing should “stop such destructive unilateral actions.”
content: China sent a record number of military aircraft toward the self-governed island democracy of Taiwan, prompting the island’s defense ministry on Monday to warn against what it called “destructive” harassment. The previous daily record of Chinese military flights near Taiwan was 91 planes, on April 10.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Raymond Moriyama, Designer of Humane Public Spaces, Dies at 93
description: His Japanese Canadian family was interned during World War II. That experience inspired him to create inviting buildings for all people.
content: Raymond Moriyama, an iconoclastic Japanese Canadian architect whose childhood experiences of racism and internment led him to design open and inviting civic spaces that shaped the city of Toronto, died there on Sept. 1. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Berzon and Sharon LaFraniere
title: How DeSantis Played Both Sides of the G.O.P. Rift Over the 2020 Election
description: The Florida governor created an election crimes unit that placated election deniers. It led to scores of “zany-burger” tips, and, according to one Republican, “Kabuki theater.”
content: It resembled a political rally more than a news conference. In November 2021, exactly one year after Donald J. Trump lost the presidential election to Joseph R. Biden Jr., Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida spoke to a raucous crowd in a hotel conference room just a few miles from Mr. Trump’s home base of Mar-a-Lago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Crevar
title: Discovering Albania’s Timeless Vjosa River
description: Amid fertile valleys, gorges, ancient ruins and mountain villages, Europe’s first wild river national park attempts to balance tourism and conservation.
content: A journey along southern Albania’s Vjosa River, one of Europe’s last undammed waterways, means traversing a landscape that looks much as it has for centuries. Flowing from Greece’s northwestern border to the Adriatic Sea, the Vjosa rushes into box canyons and gorges formed by steep forests of maples, oaks and firs. Ancient stone bridges connect its banks, spanning turquoise water. Sheep graze the valley floor, and vineyards, family farms, orchards and olive groves intermingle with fields of dandelions and red poppies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: A Rising Spy Battle Between the U.S. and China, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump to Woo Striking Union Members in Detroit, Skipping 2nd G.O.P. Debate
description: Looking past the Republican primary, Donald Trump and his campaign are already gearing up for a possible rematch with President Biden.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump is planning to travel to Detroit on the day of the next Republican primary debate, according to two Trump advisers with knowledge of the plans, injecting himself into the labor dispute between striking autoworkers and the nation’s leading auto manufacturers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar
title: Zelensky, on ‘60 Minutes,’ Warns Russia About Attacks on Power Plants
description: The Ukrainian president threatened to escalate attacks on Russia if Moscow repeated last winter’s strategy of targeting the power grid.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine threatened to escalate attacks on Russia if Moscow repeated last winter’s strategy of bombarding Ukrainian power plants that left millions of Ukrainians fighting freezing temperatures without power, heat and water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: An About-Face on Whether the 14th Amendment Bars Trump From Office
description: Steven Calabresi, a founder of the Federalist Society, recently — and forcefully — said the former president was disqualified. He has had a change of heart.
content: A little more than a month ago, a law professor who helped found the Federalist Society, the conservative legal group, enthusiastically endorsed a new law review article arguing that Donald J. Trump was ineligible to be president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: ‘Purlie Victorious’: Ossie Davis’s ‘Gospel to Humanity’ Returns to Broadway
description: The stars Leslie Odom Jr. and Kara Young and the director Kenny Leon discuss the revival, and why its satirical take on racism is still so timely.
content: Ossie Davis’s satirical play “Purlie Victorious” opened at the Cort Theater in September 1961 with Davis as the charismatic preacher Purlie Victorious Judson and Ruby Dee, his artistic collaborator and wife, playing Purlie’s green but soon-to-be-wise sidekick, Lutiebelle Gussie Mae Jenkins. Six decades later, Leslie Odom Jr. (“Hamilton”) and Kara Young (“Clyde’s,” “Cost of Living”) are stepping into those roles in the play’s first Broadway revival, directed by Kenny Leon at the Music Box Theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Rebecca Carballo
title: F-35 Jet Mystery Ends as Wreckage Is Found
description: Debris was found north of Charleston, S.C., one day after a pilot on a training mission ejected and the military lost track of his jet.
content: The United States military said on Monday evening that searchers had found the wreckage of an F-35 jet in South Carolina, one day after the Marine Corps inexplicably lost track of it when the pilot ejected with a parachute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Zelensky Cleans House in Corruption-Plagued Defense Ministry
description: On the eve of a trip to the United States, Ukraine’s president is eager to demonstrate that the billions of dollars Washington is spending to aid his country is not being squandered.
content: Two weeks after replacing its defense minister, Ukraine dismissed all six of its deputy ministers on Monday, deepening the housecleaning at a ministry that had drawn criticism for corruption in procurement as the military budget ballooned during the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: What to Expect as the U.N. Meets
description: Plus, lessons from Singapore on cooling a city.
content: The U.N. General Assembly convenes today, but of the leaders of the five permanent members of the Security Council — the U. S., Russia, China, France and Britain — only President Biden will attend.  The absences highlight increasing global divisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: California Lawmakers Push for a Court Ruling on Trump’s Eligibility
description: Nine California legislators asked the state’s attorney general to seek a court opinion on whether former President Donald J. Trump is disqualified from office under the 14th Amendment.
content: Nine California lawmakers asked the state’s attorney general in a letter on Monday to seek a court opinion on whether former President Donald J. Trump should be excluded from Republican primary ballots under the 14th Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: It’s Not an Excuse to Say the Trumps Did Worse
description: September is the cruelest month? It is if you’re Joe Biden.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, September is one of my favorite months, and I’ve always kinda wished Congress would stay out on vacation longer. They tend to be a leaky cloud on the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: How TikTok Is Reshaping the American Cookbook
description: A growing number of video stars are using their online clout to break into the publishing world — and top the best-seller lists.
content: Three years ago, B. Dylan Hollis was an unemployed musician in Wyoming who had never baked anything outside a home-economics class, much less written a recipe. Last month, his debut cookbook, “Baking Yesteryear,” became the best-selling book in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Police Arrest 29-Year-Old in Ambush Shooting of Los Angeles County Deputy
description: The deputy, Ryan Clinkunbroomer, 30, was killed Saturday night as he sat in a patrol cruiser near the sheriff’s station in Palmdale, Calif.
content: For more than a day, Los Angeles County Sheriff’s deputies scoured the high desert city of Palmdale, desperately searching for a man who killed one of their own in an ambush shooting over the weekend. They had little to go on except surveillance video showing an older, dark gray Toyota sedan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Perelman Arts Center Opens in New York and Welcomes the World
description: Global performers including Angelique Kidjo, Laurie Anderson and José Feliciano will inaugurate the theater at ground zero.
content: The first public events at the new $500 million Perelman Performing Arts Center, the opulent new theater near the site of the World Trade Center, are deliberately laden with symbolism. The center is opening its doors with five shows on Sept. 19-23, collectively titled “Refuge: A Concert Series to Welcome the World.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Do You Have a Question About the 2024 Election? We Want to Hear It.
description: As primary season gets underway, “The Run-Up” podcast will begin answering listener questions in a new, recurring segment.
content: Is the Republican primary just a race for second place? How old is too old to be president? Is it really going to be Biden vs. Trump … again?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: After a Stroke, a Writer Loses Mobility but None of His Punch
description: Jonathan Raban’s “Father and Son” is a memoir of illness and recovery paired with a parental history.
content: The problem with being a book critic, Dorothy Parker wrote, is that the work gets in the way of your reading. Jonathan Raban’s posthumous memoir, “Father and Son,” is a book I would have tracked down even if this weren’t my job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus and Jackie Molloy
title: A Summer of Singles Events, in Pictures
description: Singles mingled the summer away at one event after another, often organized by identity group, common interest or gimmicky premise — sometimes the cornier, the better.
content: At a speed-dating event in August, $25 bought attendees 20 dates with strangers, each roughly five minutes long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korean Prosecutors Want to Arrest Hunger-Striking Opposition Leader
description: Lee Jae-myung has been the subject of a series of investigations since losing the 2022 presidential election. He says his rival now runs “a dictatorship by prosecutors.​”
content: Prosecutors on Monday asked a Seoul court to issue an arrest warrant for South Korea’s leading opposition figure, Lee Jae-myung, on corruption charges, 18 days after Mr. Lee began a hunger strike to protest President Yoon Suk Yeol’s foreign and domestic policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: In U.S., Zelensky Will Make Case for More Aid, and Offer Thanks
description: The Ukrainian leader’s second trip to America comes at a more delicate  diplomatic moment, as he tries to navigate political currents while expressing gratitude for Western support.
content: A hero’s welcome awaited President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on his first trip to the United States after Russia’s full-scale invasion, which came on the heels of two back-to-back military advances that showcased Ukrainian momentum to the West. Mr. Zelensky spoke to a joint session of Congress last December, highlighting the successes and appealing for continued aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. National Debt Tops $33 Trillion for First Time
description: The fiscal milestone comes as Congress is facing a new spending fight with a government shutdown looming.
content: America’s gross national debt exceeded $33 trillion for the first time on Monday, providing a stark reminder of the country’s shaky fiscal trajectory at a moment when Washington faces the prospect of a government shutdown this month amid another fight over federal spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: Jennifer Hermoso Excluded From Spain’s Game Roster
description: The team’s new coach said she was trying to protect Ms. Hermoso, who was forcibly kissed by the Spanish soccer chief after the World Cup, by not putting her on the roster.
content: Spain unveiled its roster on Monday for the first two matches of the women’s national team since the team’s World Cup win — and a postgame kiss that plunged women’s soccer into turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Do You Multitask? Is It Helpful or Harmful?
description: A guest writer challenges readers to stop distracting themselves and do one activity at a time for a week. Do you think you could do it?
content: Do you ever watch TV while you’re doing homework? Listen to a podcast or music while driving? Talk on the phone while cleaning your room? Text or scroll while hanging out with friends?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: You Won’t Lose Weight on Ozempic Forever
description: People taking the drug and similar medications will hit an inevitable, and necessary, plateau. Here’s why.
content: Kimmy Meinecke blamed herself when she stopped losing weight. For two years, she had been taking a weekly injection of Ozempic to control her diabetes. The medication curbed her appetite so much that sometimes all she ate for dinner was a yogurt or cheese and crackers. But then one day, the scale hit 240, 25 pounds below the weight she’d started at, and stayed there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Do I Deal With a Shoes-Off Home?
description: A reader does not feel comfortable going barefoot at a host’s request.
content: Feet! They are among the most controversial, least discussed parts of the body. I know people who quail at the sight of other people’s feet, and we all know about people who fetishize feet. They can be callused, blistered, hairy, hardened and otherwise ill tended. Also smelly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Nina Feldman, Alex Stern, Luke Vander Ploeg, Shannon Lin, Lexie Diao, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Diane Wong, Elisheba Ittoop and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Ozempic Era of Weight Loss
description: The stories of two people who took the medication and had two very different experiences.
content: Drugs like Ozempic are revolutionizing the treatment of obesity. The medications, originally used to treat diabetes, keep gaining attention as celebrities and other influencers describe taking them to lose weight quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Superpower’ Review: Sean Penn Chronicles the War in Ukraine
description: This documentary, which Penn directed with Aaron Kaufman, includes Penn’s interview with the Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky on the first day of Russia’s invasion.
content: Near the beginning of “Superpower,” Sean Penn tries to pre-empt the criticism generated by his previous trips to conflict zones. “Weathered though it is,” he says in narration, “my famous face gets me access to places and people I may otherwise not have known.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Wiegand
title: Injuries in Brazilian Jujitsu Prompt Introspection in Growing Martial Art
description: Brazilian jujitsu, a self-defense form popularized by its use in mixed martial arts, is seeing new conflicts with less oversight than some other combat sports.
content: When Erik Milosevich attended his first Brazilian jujitsu class, he hoped it would spark a mutual interest to share with his teenage daughter. Instead, he left the gym with a limp, after injuring his left knee while sparring with an instructor, and a distaste for one of the fastest-growing martial arts for self-defense and competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: First Trial in the Death of Elijah McClain Expected to Start This Week
description: The 23-year-old died days after an encounter with the police and paramedics in 2019, which prompted investigations and demand for change within the Aurora, Colo., police force.
content: Jury selection continues in a Colorado district court for the trial of two police officers indicted in the 2019 death of Elijah McClain, a young Black man who died days after being subdued by officers and paramedics. The case is split into three separate trials, the first of which is scheduled to begin this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘American Horror Story’ and Global Citizens Festival
description: Kim Kardashian takes on an acting role in this anthology series. Lauryn Hill and others are set to perform at the annual festival.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Sept. 18-24. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Unlicensed Acupuncturist Is Charged After a Patient’s Lungs Collapse
description: Practitioners who use the technique at a certain point in the upper back between the spine and shoulder blade risk puncturing a lung.
content: An unlicensed acupuncturist in Queens punctured a woman’s lungs during a treatment, leading her to pass out on the street and requiring major surgery, according to prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Some Businesses Make ‘Woke Free’ a Selling Point
description: A number of companies — from clothing to pet care — are trying to appeal to customers who think corporate America is pushing a liberal agenda.
content: Jonathan Isaac is a forward for the National Basketball Association’s Orlando Magic, but he is perhaps better known as someone who chose not to protest police brutality against Black Americans during a summer of widespread activism involving racial injustice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Editor’s note: Introducing Getting to Genius, a series where two Games editors take you through the best way to get better at Spelling Bee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Swing State’ Review: All Is Not Well in Wisconsin
description: Rebecca Gilman’s play, set in a rural farmhouse, sees an image of the decline of Americans’ interdependence in the death of wildflowers.
content: It’s immediately clear what kind of flinty, progressive woman lives in the converted farmhouse depicted onstage in “Swing State,” the play by Rebecca Gilman that opened on Sunday at the Minetta Lane Theater. Well, not so much “depicted” as “duplicated.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: ​Mark Meadows’s Testimony in Georgia Case May Have Done Him No Favors
description: Mark Meadows, a former top Trump aide, took the witness stand in hopes of having his election interference case moved to federal court. So far, the strategy has not paid off.
content: One morning last month in an Atlanta federal courtroom, Mark Meadows, former President Donald J. Trump’s final chief of staff, was in the hot seat. And he was the one who had put himself there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Striking Autoworkers Are Cool to Biden’s Embrace
description: The president has highlighted his pro-union credentials, but inflation has eroded blue-collar livelihoods and chilled support for the president on the picket lines.
content: President Biden, who calls himself the most pro-union president ever and has sided with striking United Auto Workers — calling for “record contracts” as the union walked out on Friday — has yet to convince many rank-and-file U.A.W. members that his sentiments are more than just nice-sounding words.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Chhita
title: Overlooked No More: Margaret Chung, Doctor Who Was ‘Different From Others’
description: As the first known American woman of Chinese ancestry to earn a medical degree, she treated celebrities and opened a practice in San Francisco’s Chinatown.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: What’s Next for Ukraine
description: The slow counteroffensive shows the realities of war.
content: Before Ukraine’s military began a counteroffensive in June, officials hoped they could replicate last year’s successes and quickly retake large swaths of Russian-held territory. Instead, Ukrainian forces initially made almost no progress. In recent weeks, they have made more but still captured only a few small villages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Iran Released Five American Prisoners
description: Also, Kevin McCarthy’s plan to avoid a shutdown. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Five Americans who had been imprisoned in Iran left the country today after the U.S. negotiated their release, President Biden said. The agreement involved unfreezing $6 billion in Iranian oil revenue and dismissing federal charges against five Iranians. The deal was a result of two years of high-stakes talks and is part of a larger effort by the Biden administration to de-escalate tensions with Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: How to Tell if Your A.I. Is Conscious
description: In a new report, scientists offer a list of measurable qualities that might indicate the presence of some presence in a machine.
content: Have you ever talked to someone who is “into consciousness?” How did that conversation go? Did they make a vague gesture in the air with both hands? Did they reference the Tao Te Ching or Jean-Paul Sartre? Did they say that, actually, there’s nothing scientists can be sure about, and that reality is only as real as we make it out to be?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin and Alex Traub
title: Irish Grinstead, Who Asked, ‘Where My Girls At?,’ Dies at 43
description: The song, from 1999, was the biggest hit for her, her sister and a friend, who made up the R&B trio 702.
content: Irish Grinstead, a member of the R&B trio 702, best known for their 1999 hit, “Where My Girls At?,” died on Saturday. She was 43.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: Why Miró’s Yellows Have Lost Their Brilliance
description: Researchers discovered that a particular brand of paint favored by the Spanish artist had an atomic structure that predisposed it to degradation.
content: From Van Gogh’s sunflowers to Edvard Munch’s “The Scream,” there’s no shortage of seminal artwork that was made with a striking hue known as cadmium yellow. But that riot of color that artists squeezed from their paint tubes isn’t necessarily what museum goers see today: cadmium yellow’s brilliance often diminishes over time, as the paint fades and turns chalky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch and Judson Jones
title: Remnants of Hurricane Lee Will Bring Heavy Rain to the U.K.
description: Days after the storm made landfall in Canada, its remains are expected to bring rain and wind to parts of Britain that just experienced a heat wave.
content: After the powerful storm once known as Hurricane Lee traveled 3,000 miles across the Atlantic toward New England and Canada, where it made landfall on Saturday, the storm’s remnants have one more journey to make: to the coasts of Britain and Ireland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.5 Million Homes in California
description: A minimalist retreat in San Diego County, a modern farmhouse in Sonoma and a renovated 1947 house in Santa Monica.
content: This home is in San Diego County, about a 10-minute drive from the Palomar Observatory, home to the Hale Telescope. The house, which can be bought fully furnished, runs entirely on solar power and has a backup generator. It is not far from a general store at the base of Palomar Mountain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Erin Nolan
title: One of America’s First Women’s Colleges Is Accused of Paying Men More
description: Vassar, which is coeducational now, has maintained a gender-based pay gap for two decades, current and former female professors say in a recently filed lawsuit.
content: Vassar College, one of the first institutions of higher learning for women in the United States, prides itself on being a pioneer in women’s education and deeply committed to equality between the sexes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: A Key Question in Google’s Trial: How Formidable Is Its Data Advantage?
description: The government states that data is “oxygen for a search engine” and that Google’s anticompetitive behavior has given it a data fortress. Google says innovation explains its success.
content: The federal government’s first monopoly trial of the modern internet era is less than a week old, but already a central character has emerged: data. Its role, its use and its power are key issues in the Justice Department’s case against Google.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: Justin Trudeau Accuses India of a Killing on Canadian Soil
description: The Canadian leader said agents of India had assassinated a Sikh community leader in British Columbia in June. India called the accusation “absurd.”
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada said on Monday that “agents of the government of India” had carried out the assassination of a Sikh community leader in British Columbia in June, an explosive allegation that is likely to further sour relations between the two nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: Now Available: 2,000 Rhinos, Free to Good Homes With Plenty of Space
description: The animals, from a financially struggling private herd in South Africa, have been sold to a conservation group and will be released into the wild.
content: A herd of 2,000 rhinoceroses urgently in need of a new owner has finally found one: The rhinos and the farm where they live in South Africa have been purchased by a conservation group that plans to release the animals into the wild over the next decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amisha Padnani
title: A Second Look at Those Who Came First
description: The creator of Overlooked, which writes the obituaries for remarkable people in history, shares the inspiration behind a new limited series.
content: For more than five decades, whenever a new bridge, tunnel or highway opened in New York City, Omero C. Catan made it his business to be the first person onto, into or along it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Russell Brand Cancels Comedy Dates After Sexual Assault Allegations
description: The comedian was scheduled to perform three dates in Britain this month. Now they’ve been postponed.
content: Russell Brand postponed the remaining dates of a comedy tour on Monday, two days after British news organizations published an investigation in which several women accused him of sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: A Photo Can Tell the Truth About a Lie. Or a Lie About the Truth.
description: A new exhibit in Atlanta shows that a perfectly captured photograph can sometimes wake America from its slumber and inspire social change.
content: In “Let Us Now Praise Famous Men,” the poet and novelist James Agee praises the camera as “the central instrument” of his age. He believed that photography was capable of transmitting, as no other art could, “the peculiar kinds of poetic vitality which blaze in every real thing.” Only photographers like his collaborator Walker Evans, he writes, captured “the cruel radiance of what is.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: U.N. to Meet Amid Growing Divisions, and Demands From the Global South
description: With major world leaders skipping the annual event, discussions will focus on climate change, sovereign debt relief and development goals.
content: The United Nations General Assembly convenes on Tuesday in the shadow of the second year of war in Ukraine, amid a series of climate related catastrophes and at a time of increasing divisions in the world that will hamper efforts to address the litany of problems contributing to the strains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Rep. Jennifer Wexton Announces Rare Neurological Disorder Diagnosis
description: Ms. Wexton, a Democrat who disclosed a Parkinson’s diagnosis in April, will not seek re-election after learning she has progressive supranuclear palsy, for which there is no effective treatment.
content: Representative Jennifer Wexton, Democrat of Virginia, announced on Monday that she would not seek re-election next year after receiving a diagnosis of a rare neurological disorder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Wu
title: The Google Trial Is Going to Rewrite Our Future
description: These prosecutions typically spark innovation in unexpected ways.
content: The Google antitrust trial, which began last week, is ostensibly focused on the past — on a series of deals that Google made with other companies over the past two decades. The prosecution in the case, U.S. et al. v. Google, contends that Google illegally spent billions of dollars paying off Samsung and Apple to prevent anyone else from gaining a foothold in the market for online search.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: These Human-Made Natural Wonders Hide in Plain Sight
description: To hike on one of America’s long trails is to understand the power of network effects.
content: Robert Moor was a 10-year-old at summer camp when the counselors took him and his fellow campers to Mount Washington, N.H., the tallest mountain in the Northeast. At one point as they flanked the mountain a counselor told them that they were turning onto the Appalachian Trail, which extends north to neighboring Maine and all the way south to Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Where Has All the Left-Wing Money Gone?
description: Progressive groups that should be gearing up for 2024 are instead having to downsize.
content: As we stumble toward another existential election, panic is setting in among some progressive groups because the donors who buoyed them throughout the Trump years are disengaging. “Donations to progressive organizations are way down in 2023 across the board,” said a recent memo from Billy Wimsatt, executive director of the Movement Voter Project, an organization founded in 2016 that channels funds to community organizers, mostly in swing states, who engage and galvanize voters. He added, “Groups need money to make sure we have a good outcome next November. But. People. Are. Not. Donating.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh and Michael C. Bender
title: David McCormick Will Enter Pennsylvania Senate Race, One of 2024’s Biggest
description: Mr. McCormick, who lost the Republican primary to Dr. Mehmet Oz last year, is said to be preparing to enter the race to challenge Senator Bob Casey, a Democrat.
content: David McCormick, a former hedge fund executive who lost the Republican primary for Pennsylvania’s open Senate seat last year, is set to announce on Thursday that he is running again for Senate — this time against Senator Bob Casey, a Democrat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hope Reese
title: 8 Books to Help You Drink Less, or Quit Altogether
description: We asked addiction experts and people in recovery to share the titles they found most useful.
content: Six months before Kim Kearns quit drinking, she cracked open a book called, “We Are the Luckiest: The Surprising Magic of a Sober Life,” by Laura McKowen. But it “hit too close to home,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Olivia Rodrigo’s ‘Guts’ Is Her Second No. 1 Album
description: The 20-year-old singer-songwriter’s follow-up to her 2021 debut, “Sour,” has the fourth-biggest opening of any LP this year so far.
content: Olivia Rodrigo’s new album, “Guts,” has a blockbuster opening at No. 1 on Billboard’s chart, and the latest solo release by a member of BTS — V’s “Layover” — starts at No. 2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Meet Methuselah, the World’s Oldest Living Aquarium Fish
description: The nonagenarian lungfish has lived in a tank in Golden Gate Park in San Francisco since 1938.
content: In the fall of 1938, the Golden Gate Bridge had been open for a year, the United States was still recovering from the Great Depression and Franklin D. Roosevelt was in his second term as president. World War II had yet to begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Phil Mickelson Says Gambling Addiction ‘Isn’t Any Fun at All’
description: The professional golfer wrote a lengthy post on a social media platform, in which he discussed his struggle with gambling and offered a warning to bettors.
content: Phil Mickelson, the golf great whose issues with gambling have made headlines throughout the years, took to social media on Monday to share details about his addiction, and to offer a warning to potential bettors ahead of this year’s N.F.L. season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Two Pilots Die in Collision at National Championship Air Races in Reno
description: The deadly crash happened during a show that was being held for the last time at the Reno-Stead Airport, in northwest Nevada.
content: Two pilots competing in the National Championship Air Races in Reno, Nev., died on Sunday after their planes collided while landing, the Reno Air Racing Association said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: An ‘Outstanding, Fast and Easy’ One-Pan Fish Dish
description: Lidey Heuck’s winning weeknight recipe by the numbers: one 9x13-inch pan, 30 minutes, five stars, 4,000 ratings.
content: All hail the casserole dish! While I might push it aside when I’m reaching for a sheet pan, there are so many recipes that simply work better in a casserole dish. Lidey Heuck’s one-pan roasted fish with cherry tomatoes is an excellent example.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nancy Pelosi, on the 1973 Coup in Chile
description: The former House speaker writes to add some history about the U.S. role.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yoel Roth
title: Trump Attacked Me. Then Musk Did. It Wasn’t an Accident.
description: Yoel Roth argues that his experiences being attacked by Trump and Musk were part of a greater strategy — one that is changing what all of us see online.
content: When I worked at Twitter, I led the team that placed a fact-checking label on one of Donald Trump’s tweets for the first time. Following the violence of Jan. 6, I helped make the call to ban his account from Twitter altogether. Nothing prepared me for what would happen next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon and Ed Shanahan
title: Fentanyl Found Near Nap Mats at Day Care Where Boy Died, Police Say
description: A 1-year-old died in a Bronx apartment housing a day care program, and three others fell ill. Two people have been charged with murder.
content: A kilogram of fentanyl was found near mats that children used for napping at a Bronx day care site where one toddler died and three other children were hospitalized last week, the police said on Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura May Todd
title: A Designer Inspired by Dutch Still Lives and Gay Pulp Fiction
description: Bottega Veneta’s creative director Matthieu Blazy shares how he balances freedom and restraint.
content: As a child growing up in the center of Paris, Matthieu Blazy, the 39-year-old designer at the helm of Bottega Veneta, had a robust imagination. Though his father, Jacques, an art expert, and his mother, Christine Philips, a historian and researcher, would often take him and his twin sister, Julie, and their brother, Quentin, on trips abroad — to China, Mali and Burkina Faso — Blazy discovered more adventures in stories and cartoons. “I loved comics,” he said this past June at a cafe near his apartment in Milan. “Tom Sawyer was my childhood hero.” By his own account, he was a similarly spirited boy, which partly explains how he ended up at a Catholic boarding school in France and later at a military academy in England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Bear Sighting Forces Closures at Disney World
description: The black bear, which was spotted in a tree, was captured on Monday after some rides and attractions in the Magic Kingdom were closed.
content: Singing and dancing animatronic bears are a common sight at the Magic Kingdom theme park at Walt Disney World, but a bear that was spotted there on Monday was real and most likely looking for food, prompting officials to close some rides and attractions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Road From Mitt Romney to MAGA
description: Economic conservatives tried to use extremists and got used themselves.
content: So Mitt Romney is retiring from the Senate. This is bad news. As excerpts from a forthcoming biography reveal, Romney is cleareyed about what has happened to his party and, if what he says is true, is a profile in courage compared with colleagues who share his horror but are unwilling to say anything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: With a New Formula, U.S. News Rankings Boost Some State Universities
description: Responding to critics, the publication made its biggest changes to its method in four decades. But it’s unclear whether that is enough to quiet the naysayers.
content: U.S. News & World Report released on Monday the results of what it said was the most substantive overhaul of its 40-year-old college rankings empire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Anguish in an Immigrant Community After a Sheriff’s Deputy Kills 2 Teens
description: The sheriff in Syracuse, N.Y., had said his deputy acted in self-defense, but footage of the shooting cast the account into question.
content: They buried them both on Saturday: a pair of identical gray coffins, wheeled out of a hillside church and into the adopted hometown of many of the mourners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: With Striking Actors Off-Limits, Directors Get Their Close-Ups
description: Since striking movie stars are not allowed to promote studio films, filmmakers unexpectedly, and in some cases uneasily, have the spotlight to themselves.
content: For more than half a century, a coterie of critics and filmmakers has been making the case for what’s known as auteur theory: the idea that great directors are the central creative forces behind their films, shaping them just as authors shape their books.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Ex-Inmate Returns to Prison, but as a Coach
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, September 18, 2023.
content: “I was free four years before I was released.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernard E. Harcourt
title: Alabama Has a Horrible New Way of Killing People on Death Row
description: The method is not even recommended for euthanizing dogs and cats.
content: After botching a series of executions by lethal injection, the State of Alabama is planning to use nitrogen gas to put condemned prisoners to death. The first execution will amount to a human experiment, because neither Alabama nor any other state has ever tried to kill people this way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The Talk Shows Have Labor Pains
description: The Hollywood strikes and the trouble at “The Tonight Show” are a reminder that hosts are not just your TV friends. They’re also people’s bosses.
content: Let’s get one thing straight up front: Of all the people affected by the strikes in Hollywood, you do not need to pity the talk-show hosts. They are well-known, well-paid people who will, as a rule, be fine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai, Emma Bubola and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Who Are the Detainees Released by the U.S. and Iran?
description: Iran has freed five Americans, while the U.S. has agreed to unfreeze $6 billion in Iranian assets and to dismiss federal charges against five imprisoned Iranians.
content: Five Iranian Americans detained by Iran were allowed to leave the country on Monday, according to Iranian and White House officials, after an agreement was reached to free them in return for the dismissal of federal charges against five imprisoned Iranians and the unfreezing of $6 billion in Iranian assets.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Sept. 18, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Sept. 18, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Hunter Biden Sues I.R.S., Saying Disclosures by Agents Violated His Privacy
description: The suit from the president’s son says investigators for the tax agency had no right to make public details of his finances. It was filed days after he was indicted on separate gun charges.
content: Hunter Biden sued the Internal Revenue Service on Monday, saying that investigators for the agency violated his privacy rights by disclosing details to Congress and the public about his taxes and the investigation into his conduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vauhini Vara
title: Jhumpa Lahiri and Me
description: Like many Indian American fiction writers working in the shadow of Jhumpa Lahiri, I had to learn that my stories could be different — in part because America was different, too.
content: I graduated from high school in 2000, the year Jhumpa Lahiri won a Pulitzer Prize for her first book, “Interpreter of Maladies,” a collection of stories about well-off Indian immigrants and their children. I loved it. It was the first time I’d read fiction that bore some resemblance to my own privileged, suburban, Indian American life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Iraq’s Leader, Heading to U.N., Pitches Himself as Face of Change
description: Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani hopes to persuade the world that he can solve Iraq’s problems when he addresses the U.N. General Assembly this week.
content: When Iraq’s prime minister addresses the United Nations General Assembly in New York this week, he is hoping to persuade the world that he is the leader who can finally solve his country’s persistent problems of corruption and political instability — and make it a reliable partner for the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Crisis and Bailout: The Tortuous Cycle Stalking Nations in Debt
description: The government of Ghana is essentially bankrupt, and has turned to the International Monetary Fund for its 17th financial rescue since 1957.
content: Emmanuel Cherry, the chief executive of an association of Ghanaian construction companies, sat in a cafe at the edge of Accra Children’s Park, near the derelict Ferris wheel and kiddie train, as he tallied up how much money government entities owe thousands of contractors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Benjamin Netanyahu and Elon Musk Meet, as Both Seek to Deflect Criticism
description: Mr. Netanyahu, the Israeli leader, flew to California, where he met with Mr. Musk, the owner of X, formerly Twitter. In a live broadcast, the men discussed antisemitism, Israel’s judicial crisis and artificial intelligence.
content: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, and Elon Musk, the owner of X, the social media platform formerly called Twitter, have both faced intense scrutiny and criticism for most of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin and Kamil Kakol
title: Drone Attack Kills 3 Counterterrorist Fighters in Iraqi Kurdistan
description: Drone attacks in the Kurdistan region usually target insurgent groups fighting against Turkey and Iran; this one struck an elite Iraqi Kurdish security force.
content: A drone attack on a small airport killed three members of an elite Iraqi Kurdish counterterrorism task force that operates in the semiautonomous region of Kurdistan in northern Iraq.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: All the Presidents’ Children
description: Hunter Biden is just one of many presidential children who have become political problems for their parents.
content: Hunter Biden is just one of many presidential children who have become political problems for their parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, John Keefe, Judson Jones and Bea Malsky
title: Tracking Hurricane Nigel
description: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Nigel.
content: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Nigel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Climate Protesters Around the World Sharpen Their Message
description: Their demands to "End Fossil Fuels" will loom over United Nations meetings this week.
content: Their demands to "End Fossil Fuels" will loom over United Nations meetings this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pablo Robles, Josh Holder and Jeremy White
title: How to Cool Down a City
description: Singapore is rethinking its sweltering urban areas to dampen the effects of climate change. Can it be a model?
content: Singapore is rethinking its sweltering urban areas to dampen the effects of climate change. Can it be a model?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dean Spears
title: All of the Predictions Agree on One Thing: Humanity Peaks Soon
description: Most people now live in countries where two or fewer children are born for every two adults.
content: Most people now live in countries where two or fewer children are born for every two adults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Match These Novels to Their Settings in the Great Plains?
description: All or parts of 10 U.S. states make up this sprawling middle section of the country — can you connect five recent novels to their locations there?
content: All or parts of 10 U.S. states make up this sprawling middle section of the country — can you connect five recent novels to their locations there?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar, Caroline Kim and Arijeta Lajka
title: ‘I Want the World to See’: Libyan Photographer Confronts Loss in His Devastated City
description: Libyan portrait photographer Muhammad Elalwany set out to document the aftermath of the devastating floods in his hometown of Derna, only to realize many of the faces he knew are now gone. He spoke with The New York Times, sharing his personal story along with images and video captured with his camera.
content: Libyan portrait photographer Muhammad Elalwany set out to document the aftermath of the devastating floods in his hometown of Derna, only to realize many of the faces he knew are now gone. He spoke with The New York Times, sharing his personal story along with images and video captured with his camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Throop, Christina Kelso and Shane O'Neill
title: Climate Protesters March in New York City
description: Thousands of demonstrators called on President Biden and other world leaders to stop new oil and gas drilling.
content: Thousands of demonstrators called on President Biden and other world leaders to stop new oil and gas drilling.
source.name: The New York Times
